Review: Great acting and solid direction — a powerful movie. I’ve been waiting to catch this on streaming again since I first saw it in 2012, and it’s finally available on Hulu and Roku right now.
A unique take on the corrupt cops subgenre. Stallone gives the best, most nuanced performance I’ve seen from him.
This felt a lot longer than 85 minutes. I really enjoyed how this started, but once Alan Ladd started getting beat up--repeatedly--the whole thing lost a lot of energy.
Improves on Young Guns in every single way. I loved it. A fun and interesting Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid movie. I enjoyed how it was bookended, which made for an interesting twist on the story.

A romantic comedy with blood, terrorists and hostages. It’s not great, but I dug it. It’s a shame that a lot of the people who would love a new Jennifer Lopez romcom would not like the violence here. It’s her best romantic comedy since 2005.
It’s not bad, it’s just bland and very forgettable.

A decent western that's a bit too long (particularly the pretty pointless peyote plot point, that culminates in one of the best characters stupidly getting killed). But it sure is refreshing to see a western based on real people where the actors are a similar age to the people they’re portraying (see: Sam Shepard in The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford and Kris Kristofferson in Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid).

I really enjoyed this. It’s a fictionalized account of Bob Ford killing Jesse James, which, despite not being accurate, made for an entertaining 80 minutes. In this film, Bob’s motivation was founded in love for Cynthy, a woman he wanted to leave the gang for and marry. She’s horrified when he murders his ‘best friend,’ and the plot becomes a love triangle between Bob, Cynthy, and Edward Kelley (a fictional version of Edward O’Kelley, the stranger who murdered Bob Ford…

Movie: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

Review: This was filmed in six days with some of the cast from Mr. Jealousy, until they ran out of money and it was out of Noah Baumbach’s hands. He called this a “foolish experiment” and had his writing and directing credits removed when it was released without his approval.

Movie: Home Alone 2: Lost in New York
Harley Davidson and the Marlboro Man

Review: Julia Roberts gives a good early performance in Sleeping with the Enemy, but this is a better movie — both have a similar and intriguing premise. Enough is a bit dated, but I've happily watched it a couple times now. A mild domestic thriller.

Movie: JFK Revisited: Through the Looking Glass
